Award.AwardTitle: REU Pathways to Engineering: A digital REU mentoring manual

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project explores how to create on-line social networks for Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) students. These networks will be used to provide a support network for students to interact both with peers--other REU student--as well as faculty mentors. Through the process of building and maintaining an REU support network at one test site, the project seeks to understand effective practices for mentoring REU students. The resulting compendium of best practices will be widely distributed to REU participants including faculty and administrators.

The broader significance and importance of this project is to learn how to create strong support networks for REU students. Such support networks will enable REU students, some of whom have few opportunities to interact with a larger peer group, to more broadly interact with other REU students and faculty. Such support networks can be particularly advantageous for under-represented groups in STEM fields. By compiling a "digital handbook" of best mentoring practices, the project may improve the impact of REU programs across a wide range of STEM disciplines.

Project Overview

The primary goal of the REU Pathways to Engineering project is to increase the implementation and dissemination of new methods and effective use of technology to assist in making careers in engineering more accessible and attainable for underrepresented students, including women, underrepresented minorities, and first generation college students.  Project activities are designed to engage faculty, students and administrators in new ways, to improve and enhance communication, networking, and retention of students in the engineering discipline. The focus is on dissemination and implementation of new and proven mentoring and other student support methodologies, and outreach to underrepresented students.

Project Outcomes

Mentoring e-Manual

Because mentoring relationships have been shown to positively impact student success and retention in engineering, a major product of this project is an online mentoring manual. Contributors of core content and editorial feedback include PAESMEM awardees, industry leaders, and experienced educators who have made the study and practice of mentoring an integral part of their professional lives. The open contribution and editorial facility of the manual allows for moderated contribution of content and feedback which is then reviewed and posted in an ongoing cycle of peer discussion and improvement. Users of the online manual can access all information on mentoring best practices that is available in the manual, yet the design of the manual allows for mentors, administrators and students to easily access just the content that is pertinent to their particular roles. The ease of access and utility of content has been embraced by faculty and administrators.  The manual is an effective tool for improving retention and success of engineering students.

“This [manual] is quite comprehensive and offers some excellent advice and suggestions on mentoring…so much so that I think all college students should have access to it.” - Arlene Anderson, Director, Employer Relations & Internships, University of New Haven

Social Media Review

Another project output is a review of the use of social media tools by program personnel in engineering and other disciplines. A series of interviews and analysis resulted in several dissemination and academic discussion pieces, including an article in the Chronicle of Higher Education highlighting the link between fundamental program goals and major social media platforms that best support them. IBP also planned and facilitated two expert panels and three poster presentations at engineering education conferences, each of which sparked discussion among faculty and administrators on experiences and best practices. The findings have served to frame ongoing community discussions on best practices and potential applications of social media for furthering program goals, and supporting students entering and continuing on their STEM pathways.

A third major product is the Pathways to Engineering web portal, which will continue to serve the engineering community going forward.  Mainly an outreach and recruitment tool, it also provides a new channel for the access of resources and delivery of the educational materials.
